UK recruit Malik Newman a scoring sensation

Mississippi guard still wide-open in recruiting process

UK recruit Malik Newman a scoring sensation

Steve Jones, swjones1@courier-journal.com 4:30 p.m. EST December 8, 2014

Mississippi guard talks at Marshall County, Ky., Hoop Fest

Malik Newman has a chance to win a third-straight Player of the Year.(Photo: File photo/The Clarion-Ledger)

CONNECT 11 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

BENTON, Ky. Malik Newman did at the Marshall County Hoop Fest what he tends to do: score points in bunches.

When it came to discussing his recruitment, it was fairly typical Newman, too. He didn't have much to say, and he doesn't seem too far along in the process.

Although the five-star shooting guard from Jackson, Miss., said he hasn't even formed a list of colleges, it appears the University of Kentucky remains as well-positioned in the race as anyone. Newman and his father had only good things to say about John Calipari's Wildcats and their recent visit to Lexington.

"What can you not like about Kentucky?" his dad, Horatio Webster, said. "Kentucky is a program that speaks for itself. Coach Cal does a great job. Kentucky is Kentucky. You see what they're doing now. You have got to really love everything about Kentucky."

Newman's team, Callaway High, lost two games at Marshall County, but he was sensational, scoring 35 points on Friday night against Archbishop Carroll of Pennsylvania and 42 on Saturday night against Orangeville Prep of Canada. The second performance was four points shy of the Hoop Fest record set by another Jackson great, Monta Ellis, in 2004.

Even as defenses key on him, Newman regularly takes and makes some of the most difficult shots of any player in high school basketball deep threes, midrange jumpers, contested shots in the lane and they're usually created off the dribble from his fantastic array of crossovers, stepbacks, stop-and-pops and fadeaways.

"Malik's biggest strength is his ability to go out and get points, and I think he's really good at creating shot opportunities for himself," said top Scout.com analyst Evan Daniels, whose site ranks Newman No. 11 nationally. "He may be the best in the 2015 class at creating space and being able to pull up and make 3-pointers.

"I think he's a tremendous talent with a really quick first step. His strength relies on his ability to go out and get buckets."

UK assistant Kenny Payne and Kansas head coach Bill Self watched him on Saturday night, and those teams are seen as key contenders for Newman, although he says he's still open-minded about any school. His father played at Mississippi State, and the Bulldogs want Newman badly, too. Ole Miss is also contender, and Webster said coaches from North Carolina State, Memphis and Connecticut have visited Newman this fall as well.

Webster said his son never talks about recruiting, and no decision is expected anytime soon. No official visits are scheduled, although the family may take some over the holiday break.

"He's signing late; that's all he told me," Webster said. "My wife asked me as late as Thursday night, 'Where do you think he's going?' I said, 'I have no idea.' We're not even talking about it."

How about the prospect of Newman staying home to be a Mississippi State legacy recruit?

Webster said he's a proud former Bulldog, "but Malik didn't go to Mississippi State, so that doesn't have any bearing on Malik. Malik is going to make his own decision."

UK got to show Newman what it has to offer in mid-October when he attended Big Blue Madness on an unofficial visit. He and his dad also went to a couple UK practices.

"The Big Blue Madness was crazy," Newman said.

Said Webster: "I've never seen anything like it. It was amazing."

MORE: How does Malik Newman prep for games?

Because UK already has signed a top-flight, physical, scoring point guard New Jersey's Isaiah Briscoe and because UK guards Tyler Ulis and Devin Booker are generally expected to return as sophomores, it's conceivable that there might not be enough minutes, shots and time as the primary ball-handler available to accommodate Newman next year.

But Newman expressed a willingness to play with Briscoe in college.

"I like Briscoe," he said. "I think we could be a good backcourt together if that's the school I was to choose. Only time can tell. I think my game complements his, and his game complements mine with his New York style of play. He's always on the take (in looking to attack with the ball). I'm always on the take. You really can't double us, and it kind of opens up the floor for both of us."

And as for joining a roster that might already have former McDonald's All Americans Ulis and Booker settled in?

"I think those guys are good," Newman said. "If that was the situation I was to go to, I think those guys could really help me and push me to get to where I'm trying to."

If Calipari could pull it off and land Newman to go with Briscoe, then have Ulis and Booker return, the Cats would be incredibly formidable, even if, as expected, they lose Andrew and Aaron Harrison to the NBA draft.

"That backcourt could score a lot of points, and I can't imagine there would be too many better backcourts than that," Daniels said. "I do think that could be tough (to put together). Briscoe and Newman have some similarities in that they're both combo guards that would like to play more with the ball in their hands, but really their best attributes are their abilities to put up points.

"It'll be interesting to see. You can't ever doubt Calipari or count him out. You can always point to (2009) when he took John Wall and Eric Bledsoe two guys who played the same position and he made it work. I'm sure Cal could find a way to make it work, but it could be a tough task."

Steve Jones can be reached at (502) 582-7176 and followed on Twitter at @SteveJones_CJ.
